title: Tuesday, 29th October 2019

Anyway, if you want to know what's happening on whether we'll be shutting down pantomimes and sending pensioners to queue outside school halls in December, go here: https://www.ft.com/brexitlive

tangledodyssey Yes
BE11:11am

The Labour party will back the government's bill for a snap general election today, Sebastian Payne reports.

Following a meeting of the shadow cabinet this morning, Jeremy Corbyn, leader of the opposition, decided that his conditions had been met and the party would support the legislation.

Addressing the shadow cabinet this morning, Mr Corbyn said:

"I have consistently said that we are ready for an election and our support is subject to a No Deal Brexit being off the table.

We have now heard from the EU that the extension of Article 50 to 31st January has been confirmed, so for the next three months, our condition of taking No Deal off the table has now been met.

We will now launch the most ambitious and radical campaign for real change our country has ever seen."

11:11 am
BE11:11am

IT'S ON.

Pete Good morning all
Punter FWLIK, my prediction - con majority, and buy housebuilders for a bounce

And while Royal Mail did seem to be going better on parcels recently, this'll kick the chair from under it.

Mr Grumpy "Markets Live, the first 13 years"
BE11:16am

Here's the upshot.

BE11:16am

We downgrade Royal Mail to UW, with a Mar-20 192p Price target
(cut from 252p). We believe that with most of the short-run positive
Brexit news flow now behind us, focus will return to the companyspecific
situation and potential CWU industrial action. While the direct
cost of a strike is potentially manageable, we believe the indirect costs
of lower parcel volume and cost savings are likely material. That said,
we do not believe making concessions to the union to avoid a strike is a
sustainable strategy. Our forecasts are downgraded by c.20%, mainly
on lower cost avoidance

marktime It doesn't matter how ugly, it was priced in

We have downgraded our
FY20e PBT forecast by 19%, mainly due to £50m of lower UKPIL
cost savings. This brings our op profit forecasts to c.8% below the
bottom end of guidance (£277.5m vs £300-340m). Our Mar-20 DCFbased
target price falls to 192p (from 252p) accordingly.

Royal Mail need to do similar for all the high value London properties they have, mind you, that just buys them a few more years. Perhaps Amazon can purchase GLS

Brian Gilvary saying on the conference call that a hike now would've been "premature" and while returns will be discussed at Q4 any bump will likely have to wait until the new CEO arrives.

marktime BP yield is vulnerable to a cable reset but currently stands at about 6.4%. Boo ruddy hoo
11:28 am
BE11:28am

Citi:

BE11:28am

We had thought there might be a case to raise dividends but the decision is instead to: (a) suspend the scrip dilution and (b) honor a previous commitment to accelerate buybacks in 4Q (repurchase c. $2 B shares in 4Q vs $0.2 B in 3Q). We would think that leaves raising dividends as now an early 2020 ambition

nightingale20201 @Irish...o chance of sale and leaseback then...in particular if Corybn were in charge....
BE11:29am

And stepping backwards, RBC

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Earnings beat consensus by 7% at EBIT, driven by Rosneft & Downstream. Group EBIT of $4.5bn compares to consensus at $4.2bn and our $4.6bn estimate. The key drivers were the downstream, in particular a strong performance from fuels (BP cites record crude processed at Whiting and Cherry point in the US), as well as a better than expected performance from Rosneft ($802m vs consensus $480m). The upstream was weaker than expected, even after BP’s pre-release citing outages in the GoM.

Underlying cash flow in line with RBCe, narrowing capex guidance, but Macondo higher (again): underlying CFFO pre-Macondo was $6.46bn on our calculations, vs our $6.4bn estimate, while BP has also narrowed its capex guidance for the year from $15-17bn to “under $16bn”. Macondo charges in the quarter were ~$400m, vs our $200m estimate, which brings BP to $2.5bn for the full year. These charges have been consistently higher than our estimates, and we expect further details on the call for an update on full year guidance and any adjustments needed for tax.

Removing scrip dividend option: Gearing remains well above the usual range, at ~35.6% including leases, however BP has decided to remove its scrip dividend option going forward. Based on our recent conversations, we think some investors have been calling for a dividend per share increase in the near term, however given where the balance sheet stands, this is a prudent step in our view.

BE11:29am

We remain constructive on BP for its medium-term growth profile and improving cash flow framework. This growing profile should, over time, lead to improving returns. In the near term, we expect the focus to be on de-levering the balance sheet.

marktime And think of all the savings not having to sponsor the museums and art galleries
wayneJ How are postal votes affected by a strike?
BE11:30am

And further to the scrip, Jefferies:

1966AndAllThat @waynej good point
11:30 am
BE11:30am

The dividend was maintained at $0.1025/sh. BP indicated that the scrip dividend alternative would be suspended for 3Q. Divestment proceeds were $0.7bn in 3Q and $1.4bn YTD. However, divestments announced in 2019 totaled $7.2b at the end of 3Q and BP expects to reach the 2019-2020 target of $10bn by year end. Most of the proceeds will come from the sale of the Alaskan assets to Hilcorp for $5.6b ($4.0b up front). BP has also agreed the sale of four packages of legacy gas assets from its US Lower 48 business.

During 3Q19, BP repurchased 34m shares at a cost of $215m. The company intends to fully offset the scrip dilution since 3Q17 by the end of 2019; we estimate this scrip offset will require about $1.9b (280m shares) as of the end of 3Q. BP has repurchased approximately $500m in October and needs to repurchase another 220m shares by year-end to meet its target.

BE11:31am

And for another step back, Berenberg.

BE11:31am

Overall, we view this as a positive set of results, with strong underlying cash flow generation
and a solid operational beat relative to reduced expectations for the quarter. We believe that
the market was looking for higher quarterly dividends, and a flat DPS announcement could
come as a disappointment. However, we believe that an announcement on further
shareholder returns may now come at the full year results, with the new CEO in charge.
● We have a Buy rating and value the stock on a target multiple of 7x 2020E EV/DACF. Our
price target is GBp600.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

The Q3 operational EBIT of EUR231m was above our forecast of
EUR210m but in line with consensus of EUR233m. Per business division,
the performance was mixed. Consumer Board and Paper showed better
earnings than we had anticipated due to more favourable prices. Earnings
at the Bio Materials divisions were below our expectations, as shipments
(down by 16% YOY) were far below our assumptions. Net cash flows were
strong at EUR347m, as the company released EUR323m in NWC. Thus, net
debt stood at EUR3,973m at the end of Q3, down by EUR228m.

BE11:43am

Management guides for an op. EBIT in the range of EUR100-180m for Q4,
while costs for planned maintenance in Q4 are expected to be at the same
level QOQ and YOY. Ahead of the Q3 report, consensus looked at an op.
Q4 EBIT of EUR218m, while our forecast was EUR185m. Assuming the
mid-point at the new guidance range, the op. EBIT for FY 2019 would be
EUR982m, 7% shy of consensus at EUR1,051m (-3% assuming the high end
of the range, -10% if assuming the low end of the range).

BE11:43am

Although, the weak Q4 guidance does not change our positive view on the
stock, we are somewhat disappointed by the new Q4 guidance range and
given the recent share price performance, it is likely that the shares will
come off by a few percentage points. However, it should be said that its Q3
and Q4 earnings are always seasonally weaker, as the company is taking
most of its downtime during these two quarters. The company is in
excellent shape and we continue to regard the outlook for next year as
robust. We base our EUR13 TP on a P/E 2021E of below 13X and a yield on
this year’s DPS of 3.8%.

Canaccord:

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Highlights revenue of $110m and EBITDA of $70m for the quarter, leading to a 9-month result for revenue of $258.6m and EBITDA of $135.7m. This performance looks in-line. The company needs c.$110m of revenue and $43m of EBITDA in Q4 to hit CG and consensus forecasts. The stock trades on a CY19 PE of 8.0x, rising to 8.6x in CY20 and 8.7x in CY21 and yields 7.5%, falling to 5.8% in CY20 and 5.7% in CY21. The structural challenges e.g. Australia and ESMA region remain a real headwind. We reiterate our SELL recommendation and target price of 547p, implying 31% downside. The company is $23m through the $50m share buyback which should continue to give some support.

BE11:52am

And Peel Hunt

BE11:53am

The overall message from today’s update is that trading is in line
with expectations. Like others in the sector, Plus has benefitted
from more active markets, and revenues were up 18% on the
prior quarter. Despite this, we remain negative given the longerterm
risks and challenges facing the business model

Irish HF guy bye all for today,I need to go food shopping! Enjoy
wayneJ I wonder how much Jublia Will sell for in the UK
11:54 am
BE11:54am

Today’s update covers the quarter to 30 September and reports that overall trading is in line with expectations for the year as a whole. As others in the sector have reported, there has been more trading activity in this quarter, which led to revenues increasing by 10% on the prior quarter to $110.6m [or up 18% on the more sluggish Q2 2019]. ARPU improved by 15% on Q2 to c$1,000, highlighting the improved number of trading opportunities given geopolitical events. With the natural operating leverage in the model, EBITDA improved to $70.1m, an increase of 38% on the prior year and more than was generated in H1 2019 ($66m).

wayneJ @BE - also indirectly alluded to was the implication that pharmacists /NHS should not auto substitute with generics
BE11:54am

One of the main challenges that Plus faces is the continual
recruitment of new customers. The overall number of active customers showed modest growth over the previous quarter, to just over 110k, whilst the number of new customers fell by 7% relative to Q2 to just over 24k. However, there was a reduction in the average user acquisition cost to $921 from $956 in Q2.

BE11:55am

(@Wayne: fair enough, as I say I was only half watching.)

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Forecasts. Currently our FY19 forecast for PBT/EPS of $165.8m/114c is below consensus, which stands at $181.3m/121c. This suggests upside of c10% to our forecasts to bring us in line with consensus given the overall comment that trading is in line with expectations (EBITDA after nine months of $136m is against a FY forecast of $169m). The caveat remains trading conditions in Q4.
Valuation and recommendation. Whilst the shares continue to trade on a lowly valuation of c6x (to December 2020), there remains a high level of earnings uncertainty and longer-term margin sustainability. Customer growth is increasingly difficult and there remains a risk to the 15% of revenues generated in Australia. We retain our negative recommendation.

BE11:56am

Though I imagine Liberum's buying.

wayneJ Is worth noting in that context that the MEDIAN pre tax earnings in the US are lower than people think (lower than western Europe IIRC) - and in the US one has to pay local and federal taxes plus pay for healthinsurance etc

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Omg smile

BE11:57am

... and the company confirms it is on track for 2019. It will continue
to take share and the economics remain excellent. We take
a more cautious view of 2020, however, both of the
Australian regulatory impact, which will take 10% off
revenues, and of organic growth. Our new 2020 revenue
forecast assumes only 4% organic growth on the average
revenues of the last 3 quarters, leading to a 16% revenue
downgrade. Continued delivery of strong cashflow will
cause a higher rating over time. Given the low valuation,
high cash conversion and ongoing buyback, we reiterate
our £10 TP and BUY rating.
